story:
Once upon a time, in a small shtetl in Eastern Europe, there lived a kind and gentle Jewish mother named Fruma. Fruma had a young son named Moishe who was the light of her life. Every night, Fruma would tuck Moishe into bed and tell him a bedtime story to help him drift off to sleep.

One night, Fruma told Moishe the story of the wise old Rabbi who lived in a nearby town. This Rabbi was known far and wide for his wisdom and kindness, and people would come from all over to seek his counsel.

One day, a poor man came to the Rabbi in great distress. He had lost his job and had no way to provide for his family. He had prayed to God for help, but none seemed to come.

The Rabbi listened carefully to the man's story and then said, "Go to the river at dawn and wait there. God will provide for you."

The man was desperate and didn't understand what the Rabbi meant, but he had nothing to lose. So, he went to the river at dawn, as instructed.

As the sun began to rise, the man saw a beautiful swan swimming towards him. The swan was holding a golden ring in its beak. The man reached out and took the ring, and to his surprise, the swan transformed into a beautiful woman.

She introduced herself as the Queen of the Fairies and explained that she had been cursed to live as a swan during the day, but the golden ring had the power to break the curse.

"Take this ring and sell it," she said. "Use the money to provide for your family."

The man was overjoyed and thanked the Queen of the Fairies for her kindness. He quickly sold the ring and was able to provide for his family once again.

From that day on, the man never doubted the power of prayer or the wisdom of the Rabbi. He lived a happy and prosperous life, always remembering to be grateful for the blessings he received.

Fruma finished her story and looked down at Moishe, who had fallen asleep with a smile on his face. She kissed him gently on the forehead and whispered, "May God always provide for you and guide you on the right path."

And with that, Fruma turned off the light and left the room, grateful for the opportunity to share the story of the wise old Rabbi with her beloved son.
